Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Structural, Thermochronologic, and Provenance Investigation of a Hypothesized Transition From Subduction to Slab Breakoff in the Greater Caucasus
Award.AbstractNarration:
Slab breakoff, in which a slab detaches from a subducting plate and sinks into the mantle, exerts a first-order control on the geodynamic evolution of collisional orogenic belts because breakoff fundamentally alters the forces along the convergent margin. Modeling indicates that observable characteristics of breakoff within a collisional orogen include subduction of an ocean basin before collision, a transient pulse of accelerated rock and surface uplift in the belt, a decrease in convergence rate over the breakoff and an increase above adjacent parts of the slab that remain attached. However, geologic observations of this process within continental collision zones are not well documented. This University of California Davis and University of Michigan research team, in collaboration with their international partners, in explores the idea that the recent geological history of the Greater Caucasus (between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea) is a consequence of this process. The project will advance desired societal outcomes by: (1) development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through the training of several U.S. graduate students, involvement of undergraduate students in research, and training of graduate students from Georgia, Armenia, and Azerbaijan; (2) increased partnerships between academia and the hydrocarbon industry and strengthening of existing collaborations and the development of new collaborations with scientists in Armenia and Georgia, Taiwan, and Canada. The project would provide the graduate students with rich international research experiences. The project is supported by the Tectonics Program and NSF's International Science and Engineering program.

This research project will test the hypothesis that the Greater Caucasus reflects the transient geodynamic response to recent slab breakoff beneath the western portion of the range. This event follows the Oligocene to Pliocene closure of a remnant ocean basin, subduction of which presently continues beneath the eastern half of the range. The research team will carry out a field investigation of this little-studied orogen using structural mapping and balanced cross-sections, sediment provenance studies using U-Pb analyses of detrital zircons and (U-Th)/He analyses of apatite, bedrock low-temperature thermochronometry, and neotectonic investigations. They aim to constrain the magnitude of Cenozoic shortening across the Greater Caucasus along three orogen-perpendicular sections, and to derive the exhumation history of the Greater and Lesser Caucasus from low-temperature thermochronometry. Integration of these data with detrital provenance and lag time analyses of adjacent sedimentary basins will capture the geologic response to a transient geodynamic event and record perhaps the first evidence for slab detachment at the subduction-to-collision transition in an active orogen.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Continental collisions following subduction of an intervening ocean cause the oceanic plate to break off and sink into the mantle.  This process exerts a first-order control on the evolution of collisional orogenic belts because it fundamentally alters the forces along the convergent margin. Modeling indicates that observable characteristics of breakoff within a collisional orogen include subduction of an ocean basin before collision, a transient pulse of accelerated rock and surface uplift in the belt, a decrease in convergence rate over the breakoff and an increase above adjacent parts of the slab that remain attached. However, geologic observations of this process within continental collision zones are not well documented. In this project, a research team from the University of California Davis and the University of Michigan collaborated with international partners from Georgia, Azerbaijan, and Armenia to determine if the Greater Caucasus Mountains record slab breakoff.

In detail, we conducted field-based investigations of this little-studied orogen to test the hypothesis that the Greater Caucasus reflects the transient geodynamic response to recent slab breakoff beneath the western portion of the range following Oligocene to Pliocene closure of a remnant ocean basin. Our structural mapping along 2 profiles across the range reveals that the orogen comprises an imbricate stack of steeply inclined thrust sheets (Trexler et al., in prep. 2020a).  Our crustal-scale, balanced cross-sections across the range (Trexler et al., in prep. 2020b) indicate that the range has shortened by 170 to 200 km, consistent with the hypothesis of formation by subduction. Our sediment provenance studies using U-Pb analyses of detrital zircons show that rocks on opposite sides of the range were derived from distinct source areas (Cowgill, et al., 2016), again consistent with subduction of a basin several hundred kilometers wide. Our investigation of the Main Caucasus Thrust in Georgia indicates that this major structure served as the backstop to an accretionary wedge that grew as a result of closure of the ocean basin (Vasey et al., 2020), as documented by our detrital zircon U-Pb analyses indicating deposition on the north side of the relict basin and our 40Ar/39Ar and (U-Th)/He thermochronologic analyses that document similar levels of late Cenozoic erosion on both sided of the fault.  Our studies of active deformation in the range document that the frontal thrust of the Greater Caucasus slips at ~1mm/yr (Trexler et al., 2020), is being elastically loaded at ~4 mm/yr beneath the western Greater Caucasus (Sokhadze et al., 2018), and has broken in earthquakes with 1-3 m of surface slip in the last ~30 ka (Stahl et al., in prep. 2020).  Such data, together with our compilation of regional structures in the Greater Caucasus, support a new probabilistic seismic hazard assessment for the region (Onur et al., 2020). 

Taken together, our data are consistent with the hypothesis that the Greater Caucasus formed by collision following subduction and closure of an ocean basin a few hundred kilometers wide.  However, this view has been challenged, and while we have defended the model (Cowgill et al., 2018), unequivocal evidence of subduction and suturing in the range remains to be found.  Our work clearly identifies where to look for such evidence and we are planning future work to pursue that question.  Unequivocal evidence of subduction, combined with results from our past work, would demonstrate that the Caucasus capture the transient geologic response to slab detachment during the subduction-to-collision transition in an active orogen.

This project advanced desired societal outcomes by: (1) contributing to a globally competitive STEM workforce through the training of 3 U.S. graduate students (1 PhD and 1 MS completed, 1 PhD started, initial graduate training of a PhD student now working on another project), involvement of undergraduate students in research through a capstone research course, and training of graduate students from Georgia, Armenia, and Azerbaijan; (2) increased collaboration between academia and the hydrocarbon industry and strengthening of existing collaborations and the development of new collaborations with scientists in Armenia, Georgia, Azerbaijan, and New Zealand. The project provided the graduate students with rich international research experiences and was supported by the Tectonics Program and NSF's International Science and Engineering program.
